mn67:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā cātumāyaṃ viharati āmalakīvane.
mn67:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Cātumā in a myrobalan grove.
mn67:1.2.comm: Cātumā is a Sakyan town mentioned only here. | The introduction is similar to Ud 3.3.

mn67:2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena sāriputtamoggallānappamukhāni pañcamattāni bhikkhusatāni cātumaṃ anuppattāni honti bhagavantaṃ dassanāya.
mn67:2.1.eng: Now at that time five hundred mendicants headed by Sāriputta and Moggallāna arrived at Cātumā to see the Buddha.

mn67:2.2.pli: Te ca āgantukā bhikkhū nevāsikehi bhikkhūhi saddhiṃ paṭisammodamānā senāsanāni paññāpayamānā pattacīvarāni paṭisāmayamānā uccāsaddā mahāsaddā ahesuṃ.
mn67:2.2.eng: And the visiting mendicants, while exchanging pleasantries with the resident mendicants, preparing their lodgings, and putting away their bowls and robes, made a colossal racket.

mn67:3.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ āmantesi:
mn67:3.1.eng: Then the Buddha said to Venerable Ānanda,

mn67:3.2.pli: “ke panete, ānanda, uccāsaddā mahāsaddā, kevaṭṭā maññe macchavilope”ti?
mn67:3.2.eng: “Ānanda, who’s making that colossal racket? You’d think it was fishermen hauling in a catch!”

mn67:3.3.pli: “Etāni, bhante, sāriputtamoggallānappamukhāni pañcamattāni bhikkhusatāni cātumaṃ anuppattāni bhagavantaṃ dassanāya.
mn67:3.3.eng: And Ānanda told him what had happened.

mn67:3.4.pli: Te āgantukā bhikkhū nevāsikehi bhikkhūhi saddhiṃ paṭisammodamānā senāsanāni paññāpayamānā pattacīvarāni paṭisāmayamānā uccāsaddā mahāsaddā”ti.

mn67:4.1.eng: “Well then, Ānanda, in my name tell those mendicants that

mn67:4.3.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho āyasmā ānando bhagavato paṭissutvā yena te bhikkhū tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā te bhikkhū etadavoca:
mn67:4.3.eng: “Yes, sir,” Ānanda replied. He went to those mendicants and said,

mn67:4.5.pli: “Evamāvuso”ti kho te bhikkhū āyasmato ānandassa paṭissutvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinne kho te bhikkhū bhagavā etadavoca:
mn67:4.5.eng: “Yes, reverend,” replied those mendicants. Then they rose from their seats and went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to them:

mn67:4.6.pli: “kiṃ nu tumhe, bhikkhave, uccāsaddā mahāsaddā, kevaṭṭā maññe macchavilope”ti?
mn67:4.6.eng: “Mendicants, what’s with that colossal racket? You’d think it was fishermen hauling in a catch!”

mn67:4.7.pli: “Imāni, bhante, sāriputtamoggallānappamukhāni pañcamattāni bhikkhusatāni cātumaṃ anuppattāni bhagavantaṃ dassanāya.
mn67:4.7.eng: And they told him what had happened.

mn67:4.8.pli: Teme āgantukā bhikkhū nevāsikehi bhikkhūhi saddhiṃ paṭisammodamānā senāsanāni paññāpayamānā pattacīvarāni paṭisāmayamānā uccāsaddā mahāsaddā”ti.

mn67:5.1.pli: “Gacchatha, bhikkhave, paṇāmemi vo, na vo mama santike vatthabban”ti.
mn67:5.1.eng: “Go away, mendicants, I dismiss you. You are not to stay in my presence.”

mn67:5.2.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paṭissutvā uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā senāsanaṃ saṃsāmetvā pattacīvaramādāya pakkamiṃsu.
mn67:5.2.eng: “Yes, sir,” replied those mendicants. They got up from their seats, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on their right. They set their lodgings in order and left, taking their bowls and robes.

mn67:6.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena cātumeyyakā sakyā santhāgāre sannipatitā honti kenacideva karaṇīyena.
mn67:6.1.eng: Now at that time the Sakyans of Cātumā were sitting together at the town hall on some business.

mn67:6.2.pli: Addasaṃsu kho cātumeyyakā sakyā te bhikkhū dūratova āgacchante;
mn67:6.2.eng: Seeing those mendicants coming off in the distance,

mn67:6.3.pli: disvāna yena te bhikkhū tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā te bhikkhū etadavocuṃ:
mn67:6.3.eng: they went up to them and said,

mn67:6.5.eng: “Good sirs, the mendicant Saṅgha has been dismissed by the Buddha.”

mn67:6.6.pli: “Tenahāyasmanto muhuttaṃ nisīdatha, appeva nāma mayaṃ sakkuṇeyyāma bhagavantaṃ pasādetun”ti.
mn67:6.6.eng: “Well then, venerables, sit here for an hour. Hopefully we’ll be able to restore the Buddha’s confidence.”

mn67:6.7.pli: “Evamāvuso”ti kho te bhikkhū cātumeyyakānaṃ sakyānaṃ paccassosuṃ.

mn67:7.1.pli: Atha kho cātumeyyakā sakyā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho cātumeyyakā sakyā bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
mn67:7.1.eng: Then the Sakyans of Cātumā went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

mn67:7.2.eng: “May the Buddha be happy with the mendicant Saṅgha!

mn67:7.3.eng: May the Buddha welcome the mendicant Saṅgha!

mn67:7.4.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhante, bhagavatā pubbe bhikkhusaṅgho anuggahito; evameva bhagavā etarahi anuggaṇhātu bhikkhusaṅghaṃ.
mn67:7.4.eng: May the Buddha support the mendicant Saṅgha now as he did in the past!

mn67:7.5.pli: Santettha, bhante, bhikkhū navā acirapabbajitā adhunāgatā imaṃ dhammavinayaṃ.
mn67:7.5.eng: There are mendicants here who are junior, recently gone forth, newly come to this teaching and training.

mn67:7.6.pli: Tesaṃ bhagavantaṃ dassanāya alabhantānaṃ siyā aññathattaṃ, siyā vipariṇāmo.
mn67:7.6.eng: If they don’t get to see the Buddha they may change and fall apart.

mn67:7.7.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhante, bījānaṃ taruṇānaṃ udakaṃ alabhantānaṃ siyā aññathattaṃ siyā vipariṇāmo;
mn67:7.7.eng: If young seedlings don’t get water they may change and fall apart.

mn67:7.8.pli: evameva kho, bhante, santettha bhikkhū navā acirapabbajitā adhunāgatā imaṃ dhammavinayaṃ, tesaṃ bhagavantaṃ dassanāya alabhantānaṃ siyā aññathattaṃ, siyā vipariṇāmo.
mn67:7.8.eng: In the same way, there are mendicants here who are junior, recently gone forth, newly come to this teaching and training. If they don’t get to see the Buddha they may change and fall apart.

mn67:7.9.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhante, vacchassa taruṇassa mātaraṃ apassantassa siyā aññathattaṃ, siyā vipariṇāmo;
mn67:7.9.eng: If a young calf doesn’t see its mother it may change and fall apart.

mn67:7.10.pli: evameva kho, bhante, santettha bhikkhū navā acirapabbajitā adhunāgatā imaṃ dhammavinayaṃ, tesaṃ bhagavantaṃ apassantānaṃ siyā aññathattaṃ, siyā vipariṇāmo.
mn67:7.10.eng: In the same way, there are mendicants here who are junior, recently gone forth, newly come to this teaching and training. If they don’t get to see the Buddha they may change and fall apart.

mn67:7.11.eng: May the Buddha be happy with the mendicant Saṅgha!

mn67:7.12.eng: May the Buddha welcome the mendicant Saṅgha!

mn67:7.13.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhante, bhagavatā pubbe bhikkhusaṅgho anuggahito; evameva bhagavā etarahi anuggaṇhātu bhikkhusaṅghan”ti.
mn67:7.13.eng: May the Buddha support the mendicant Saṅgha now as he did in the past!”

mn67:8.1.pli: Atha kho brahmā sahampati bhagavato cetasā cetoparivitakkamaññāya—seyyathāpi nāma balavā puriso samiñjitaṃ vā bāhaṃ pasāreyya, pasāritaṃ vā bāhaṃ samiñjeyya; evameva—brahmaloke antarahito bhagavato purato pāturahosi.
mn67:8.1.eng: Then the divinity Sahampati knew what the Buddha was thinking. As easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, he vanished from the realm of divinity and reappeared in front of the Buddha.

mn67:8.2.pli: Atha kho brahmā sahampati ekaṃsaṃ uttarāsaṅgaṃ karitvā yena bhagavā tenañjaliṃ paṇāmetvā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn67:8.2.eng: He arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha, and said:

mn67:9.1.eng: “May the Buddha be happy with the mendicant Saṅgha!

mn67:9.2.eng: May the Buddha welcome the mendicant Saṅgha!

mn67:9.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhante, bhagavatā pubbe bhikkhusaṅgho anuggahito; evameva bhagavā etarahi anuggaṇhātu bhikkhusaṅghaṃ.
mn67:9.3.eng: May the Buddha support the mendicant Saṅgha now as he did in the past!

mn67:9.4.pli: Santettha, bhante, bhikkhū navā acirapabbajitā adhunāgatā imaṃ dhammavinayaṃ, tesaṃ bhagavantaṃ dassanāya alabhantānaṃ siyā aññathattaṃ, siyā vipariṇāmo.
mn67:9.4.eng: There are mendicants here who are junior, recently gone forth, newly come to this teaching and training. If they don’t get to see the Buddha they may change and fall apart.

mn67:9.5.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhante, bījānaṃ taruṇānaṃ udakaṃ alabhantānaṃ siyā aññathattaṃ, siyā vipariṇāmo;
mn67:9.5.eng: If young seedlings don’t get water they may change and fall apart. …

mn67:9.6.pli: evameva kho, bhante, santettha bhikkhū navā acirapabbajitā adhunāgatā imaṃ dhammavinayaṃ, tesaṃ bhagavantaṃ dassanāya alabhantānaṃ siyā aññathattaṃ, siyā vipariṇāmo.

mn67:9.7.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhante, vacchassa taruṇassa mātaraṃ apassantassa siyā aññathattaṃ, siyā vipariṇāmo;
mn67:9.7.eng: If a young calf doesn’t see its mother it may change and fall apart.

mn67:9.8.pli: evameva kho, bhante, santettha bhikkhū navā acirapabbajitā adhunāgatā imaṃ dhammavinayaṃ, tesaṃ bhagavantaṃ apassantānaṃ siyā aññathattaṃ, siyā vipariṇāmo.
mn67:9.8.eng: In the same way, there are mendicants here who are junior, recently gone forth, newly come to this teaching and training. If they don’t get to see the Buddha they may change and fall apart.

mn67:9.9.eng: May the Buddha be happy with the mendicant Saṅgha!

mn67:9.10.eng: May the Buddha welcome the mendicant Saṅgha!

mn67:9.11.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhante, bhagavatā pubbe bhikkhusaṅgho anuggahito; evameva bhagavā etarahi anuggaṇhātu bhikkhusaṅghan”ti.
mn67:9.11.eng: May the Buddha support the mendicant Saṅgha now as he did in the past!”

mn67:10.1.pli: Asakkhiṃsu kho cātumeyyakā ca sakyā brahmā ca sahampati bhagavantaṃ pasādetuṃ bījūpamena ca taruṇūpamena ca.
mn67:10.1.eng: The Sakyans of Cātumā and the divinity Sahampati were able to restore the Buddha’s confidence with the similes of the seedlings and the calf.

mn67:11.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mahāmoggallāno bhikkhū āmantesi:
mn67:11.1.eng: Then Venerable Mahāmoggallāna addressed the mendicants,

mn67:11.2.eng: “Get up, reverends, and pick up your bowls and robes.

mn67:11.3.pli: Pasādito bhagavā cātumeyyakehi ca sakyehi brahmunā ca sahampatinā bījūpamena ca taruṇūpamena cā”ti.
mn67:11.3.eng: The Buddha’s confidence has been restored by the Sakyans of Cātumā and the divinity Sahampati with the similes of the seedlings and the calf.”

mn67:12.1.pli: “Evamāvuso”ti kho te bhikkhū āyasmato mahāmoggallānassa paṭissutvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pattacīvaramādāya yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
mn67:12.1.eng: “Yes, reverend,” replied those mendicants. Then they rose from their seats and, taking their bowls and robes, went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to Venerable Sāriputta,

mn67:12.2.pli: “kinti te, sāriputta, ahosi mayā bhikkhusaṅghe paṇāmite”ti?
mn67:12.2.eng: “Sāriputta, what did you think when the mendicant Saṅgha was dismissed by me?”

mn67:12.4.eng: ‘The Buddha has dismissed the mendicant Saṅgha.

mn67:12.5.pli: Appossukko dāni bhagavā diṭṭhadhammasukhavihāraṃ anuyutto viharissati, mayampi dāni appossukkā diṭṭhadhammasukhavihāramanuyuttā viharissāmā’”ti.
mn67:12.5.eng: Now he will remain passive, dwelling in blissful meditation in this life, and so will we.’”

mn67:12.6.pli: “Āgamehi tvaṃ, sāriputta, āgamehi tvaṃ, sāriputta, diṭṭhadhammasukhavihāran”ti.
mn67:12.6.eng: “Hold on, Sāriputta, hold on! Don’t you ever think such a thing again!”
mn67:12.6.comm: The PTS reading is preferable: na kho te Sāriputta puna pi evarūpaṁ cittaṁ uppādetabbanti.

mn67:13.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ mahāmoggallānaṃ āmantesi:
mn67:13.1.eng: Then the Buddha addressed Venerable Mahāmoggallāna,

mn67:13.2.pli: “kinti te, moggallāna, ahosi mayā bhikkhusaṅghe paṇāmite”ti?
mn67:13.2.eng: “Moggallāna, what did you think when the mendicant Saṅgha was dismissed by me?”

mn67:13.4.eng: ‘The Buddha has dismissed the mendicant Saṅgha.

mn67:13.5.pli: Appossukko dāni bhagavā diṭṭhadhammasukhavihāraṃ anuyutto viharissati, ahañca dāni āyasmā ca sāriputto bhikkhusaṅghaṃ pariharissāmā’”ti.
mn67:13.5.eng: Now he will remain passive, dwelling in blissful meditation in this life. Meanwhile, Venerable Sāriputta and I shall lead the mendicant Saṅgha.’”

mn67:13.7.pli: Ahaṃ vā hi, moggallāna, bhikkhusaṅghaṃ parihareyyaṃ sāriputtamoggallānā vā”ti.
mn67:13.7.eng: For either I should lead the mendicant Saṅgha, or else Sāriputta and Moggallāna.”

mn67:14.1.eng: Then the Buddha said to the mendicants:

mn67:14.2.eng: “Mendicants, when you go into the water you should anticipate four dangers.

mn67:14.4.eng: The dangers of waves, gharials, whirlpools, and sharks.

mn67:14.5.pli: imāni, bhikkhave, cattāri bhayāni udakorohante pāṭikaṅkhitabbāni.
mn67:14.5.eng: These are the four dangers that you should anticipate when you go into the water.

mn67:15.1.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, cattārimāni bhayāni idhekacce puggale imasmiṃ dhammavinaye agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajite pāṭikaṅkhitabbāni.
mn67:15.1.eng: In the same way, an individual gone forth from the lay life to homelessness in this teaching and training should anticipate four dangers.

mn67:15.3.eng: The dangers of waves, gharials, whirlpools, and sharks.

mn67:16.1.eng: And what, mendicants, is the danger of waves?
mn67:16.1.comm: Indian literature uses the wave as metaphor for a “surge” of disturbing emotion.

mn67:16.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco kulaputto saddhā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito hoti:
mn67:16.2.eng: It’s when a gentleman has gone forth out of faith from the lay life to homelessness, thinking:

mn67:16.3.pli: ‘otiṇṇomhi jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi dukkhotiṇṇo dukkhapareto;
mn67:16.3.eng: ‘I’m swamped by rebirth, old age, and death; by sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. I’m swamped by suffering, mired in suffering.

mn67:16.4.pli: appeva nāma imassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa antakiriyā paññāyethā’ti.
mn67:16.4.eng: Hopefully I can make an end to this entire mass of suffering.’

mn67:16.5.pli: Tamenaṃ tathā pabbajitaṃ samānaṃ sabrahmacārī ovadanti, anusāsanti:
mn67:16.5.eng: When they’ve gone forth, their spiritual companions advise and instruct them:

mn67:16.6.pli: ‘evaṃ te abhikkamitabbaṃ, evaṃ te paṭikkamitabbaṃ, evaṃ te ālokitabbaṃ, evaṃ te vilokitabbaṃ, evaṃ te samiñjitabbaṃ, evaṃ te pasāritabbaṃ, evaṃ te saṅghāṭipattacīvaraṃ dhāretabban’ti.
mn67:16.6.eng: ‘You should go out like this, and come back like that. You should look to the front like this, and to the side like that. You should contract your limbs like this, and extend them like that. This is how you should bear your outer robe, bowl, and robes.’
mn67:16.6.comm: These activities are elsewhere framed as the practice of “situational awareness” (MN 10:8.1).

mn67:16.8.pli: ‘mayaṃ kho pubbe agāriyabhūtā samānā aññe ovadāma, anusāsāma.
mn67:16.8.eng: ‘Formerly, as laypeople, we advised and instructed others.
mn67:16.8.comm: When challenged, he uses the plural as a defense mechanism, disguising his personal reaction as an undefined “us”, implicating the Saṅgha as a whole.

mn67:16.9.pli: Ime panamhākaṃ puttamattā maññe, nattamattā maññe, amhe ovaditabbaṃ anusāsitabbaṃ maññantī’ti.
mn67:16.9.eng: And now these mendicants—who you’d think were our children or grandchildren—imagine they can advise and instruct us!’

mn67:16.10.eng: They resign the training and return to a lesser life.

mn67:16.11.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, ūmibhayassa bhīto sikkhaṃ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvatto.
mn67:16.11.eng: This is called a mendicant who resigns the training and returns to a lesser life for fear of the danger of waves.

mn67:16.12.eng: ‘Danger of waves’ is a term for anger and distress.

mn67:17.1.eng: And what, mendicants, is the danger of gharials?
mn67:17.1.comm: The gharial is a large crocodilian of the Ganges. The adult male has a distinctive “pot” (ghara) at the tip of its snout, from which it takes its name. The Pali kumbhīla (Sanskrit kumbhīra) similarly stems from kumbha, “pot”. Gharials can be seen breaking water to swallow fish, their long toothy snouts making them an apt symbol for gluttony. | Referenced by the nun Sumedhā in her verses at Thig 16.1:55.3.

mn67:17.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco kulaputto saddhā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito hoti:
mn67:17.2.eng: It’s when a gentleman has gone forth out of faith from the lay life to homelessness, thinking:

mn67:17.3.pli: ‘otiṇṇomhi jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi dukkhotiṇṇo dukkhapareto;
mn67:17.3.eng: ‘I’m swamped by rebirth, old age, and death; by sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. I’m swamped by suffering, mired in suffering.

mn67:17.4.pli: appeva nāma imassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa antakiriyā paññāyethā’ti.
mn67:17.4.eng: Hopefully I can make an end to this entire mass of suffering.’

mn67:17.5.pli: Tamenaṃ tathā pabbajitaṃ samānaṃ sabrahmacārī ovadanti anusāsanti:
mn67:17.5.eng: When they’ve gone forth, their spiritual companions advise and instruct them:

mn67:17.6.pli: ‘idaṃ te khāditabbaṃ, idaṃ te na khāditabbaṃ; idaṃ te bhuñjitabbaṃ, idaṃ te na bhuñjitabbaṃ; idaṃ te sāyitabbaṃ, idaṃ te na sāyitabbaṃ; idaṃ te pātabbaṃ, idaṃ te na pātabbaṃ; kappiyaṃ te khāditabbaṃ, akappiyaṃ te na khāditabbaṃ; kappiyaṃ te bhuñjitabbaṃ, akappiyaṃ te na bhuñjitabbaṃ; kappiyaṃ te sāyitabbaṃ, akappiyaṃ te na sāyitabbaṃ; kappiyaṃ te pātabbaṃ, akappiyaṃ te na pātabbaṃ; kāle te khāditabbaṃ, vikāle te na khāditabbaṃ; kāle te bhuñjitabbaṃ, vikāle te na bhuñjitabbaṃ; kāle te sāyitabbaṃ, vikāle te na sāyitabbaṃ; kāle te pātabbaṃ, vikāle te na pātabban’ti.
mn67:17.6.eng: ‘You may eat, consume, taste, and drink these things, but not those. You may eat what’s allowable, but not what’s unallowable. You may eat at the right time, but not at the wrong time.’

mn67:17.7.pli: Tassa evaṃ hoti: ‘mayaṃ kho pubbe agāriyabhūtā samānā yaṃ icchāma taṃ khādāma, yaṃ na icchāma na taṃ khādāma; yaṃ icchāma taṃ bhuñjāma, yaṃ na icchāma na taṃ bhuñjāma; yaṃ icchāma taṃ sāyāma, yaṃ na icchāma na taṃ sāyāma; yaṃ icchāma taṃ pivāma, yaṃ na icchāma na taṃ pivāma;
mn67:17.7.eng: They think: ‘Formerly, as laypeople, we used to eat, consume, taste, and drink what we wanted, not what we didn’t want.

mn67:17.8.pli: kappiyampi khādāma, akappiyampi khādāma; kappiyampi bhuñjāma, akappiyampi bhuñjāma; kappiyampi sāyāma, akappiyampi sāyāma; kappiyampi pivāma, akappiyampi pivāma; kālepi khādāma, vikālepi khādāma; kālepi bhuñjāma vikālepi bhuñjāma; kālepi sāyāma, vikālepi sāyāma; kālepi pivāma, vikālepi pivāma.
mn67:17.8.eng: We ate and drank both allowable and unallowable things, at the right time and the wrong time.

mn67:17.9.pli: Yampi no saddhā gahapatikā divā vikāle paṇītaṃ khādanīyaṃ bhojanīyaṃ denti tatthapime mukhāvaraṇaṃ maññe karontī’ti.
mn67:17.9.eng: And these faithful householders give us delicious fresh and cooked foods at the wrong time of day. But these guys imagine they can gag our mouths!’

mn67:17.10.eng: They resign the training and return to a lesser life.

mn67:17.11.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, kumbhīlabhayassa bhīto sikkhaṃ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvatto.
mn67:17.11.eng: This is called one who disavows the training and returns to a lesser life because they’re afraid of the danger of gharials.

mn67:17.12.eng: ‘Danger of gharials’ is a term for gluttony.

mn67:18.1.eng: And what, mendicants, is the danger of whirlpools?
mn67:18.1.comm: Āvaṭṭa means a “whirlpool”, but also to “revert”. Cf. the “return to a lesser life” (hīnāyāvattati).

mn67:18.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco kulaputto saddhā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito hoti:
mn67:18.2.eng: It’s when a gentleman has gone forth out of faith from the lay life to homelessness, thinking:

mn67:18.3.pli: ‘otiṇṇomhi jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi dukkhotiṇṇo dukkhapareto;
mn67:18.3.eng: ‘I’m swamped by rebirth, old age, and death; by sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. I’m swamped by suffering, mired in suffering.

mn67:18.4.pli: appeva nāma imassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa antakiriyā paññāyethā’ti.
mn67:18.4.eng: Hopefully I can make an end to this entire mass of suffering.’

mn67:18.5.pli: So evaṃ pabbajito samāno pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya gāmaṃ vā nigamaṃ vā piṇḍāya pavisati.
mn67:18.5.eng: When they’ve gone forth, they robe up in the morning and, taking their bowl and robe, enter a village or town for alms without guarding body, speech, and mind, without establishing mindfulness, and without restraining the sense faculties.

mn67:18.6.pli: Arakkhiteneva kāyena arakkhitāya vācāya anupaṭṭhitāya satiyā asaṃvutehi indriyehi so tattha passati gahapatiṃ vā gahapatiputtaṃ vā pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappitaṃ samaṅgībhūtaṃ paricārayamānaṃ.
mn67:18.6.eng: There they see a householder or their child amusing themselves, supplied and provided with the five kinds of sensual stimulation.

mn67:18.8.pli: ‘mayaṃ kho pubbe agāriyabhūtā samānā pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappitā samaṅgībhūtā paricārimhā.
mn67:18.8.eng: ‘Formerly, as laypeople, we amused ourselves, supplied and provided with the five kinds of sensual stimulation.

mn67:18.9.pli: Saṃvijjanti kho pana me kule bhogā.
mn67:18.9.eng: And it’s true that my family is wealthy.
mn67:18.9.comm: Here he reverts to the singular in his reflections. Obviously not all of his spiritual companions enjoy the same cushion.

mn67:18.10.pli: Sakkā bhoge ca bhuñjituṃ puññāni ca kātun’ti.
mn67:18.10.eng: I can both enjoy my wealth and make merit.’

mn67:18.11.eng: They resign the training and return to a lesser life.

mn67:18.12.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, āvaṭṭabhayassa bhīto sikkhaṃ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvatto.
mn67:18.12.eng: This is called one who disavows the training and returns to a lesser life for fear of the danger of whirlpools.

mn67:18.13.eng: ‘Danger of whirlpools’ is a term for the five kinds of sensual stimulation.

mn67:19.1.eng: And what, mendicants, is the danger of sharks?
mn67:19.1.comm: The susukā is said to be a carnivorous fish (caṇḍamaccha). The Sanskrit form śuṣkala is said to mean both a species of fish and also “flesh”. The pun appears to be between susukā and susukāḷakesā, a stock description of attractive young people with “pristine black hair”. The bull shark, which is one of several shark species prowling the Ganges, has black-tipped fins.

mn67:19.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco kulaputto saddhā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito hoti:
mn67:19.2.eng: It’s when a gentleman has gone forth out of faith from the lay life to homelessness, thinking:

mn67:19.3.pli: ‘otiṇṇomhi jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi dukkhotiṇṇo dukkhapareto;
mn67:19.3.eng: ‘I’m swamped by rebirth, old age, and death; by sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. I’m swamped by suffering, mired in suffering.

mn67:19.4.pli: appeva nāma imassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa antakiriyā paññāyethā’ti.
mn67:19.4.eng: Hopefully I can make an end to this entire mass of suffering.’

mn67:19.5.pli: So evaṃ pabbajito samāno pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya gāmaṃ vā nigamaṃ vā piṇḍāya pavisati.
mn67:19.5.eng: When they’ve gone forth, they robe up in the morning and, taking their bowl and robe, enter a village or town for alms without guarding body, speech, and mind, without establishing mindfulness, and without restraining the sense faculties.

mn67:19.6.pli: Arakkhiteneva kāyena arakkhitāya vācāya anupaṭṭhitāya satiyā asaṃvutehi indriyehi so tattha passati mātugāmaṃ dunnivatthaṃ vā duppārutaṃ vā.
mn67:19.6.eng: There they see a lady scantily clad, with revealing clothes.

mn67:19.7.pli: Tassa mātugāmaṃ disvā dunnivatthaṃ vā duppārutaṃ vā rāgo cittaṃ anuddhaṃseti.

mn67:19.8.pli: So rāgānuddhaṃsena cittena sikkhaṃ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattati.
mn67:19.8.eng: so they resign the training and return to a lesser life.

mn67:19.9.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, susukābhayassa bhīto sikkhaṃ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvatto.
mn67:19.9.eng: This is called one who disavows the training and returns to a lesser life for fear of the danger of sharks.

mn67:19.10.eng: ‘Danger of sharks’ is a term for ladies.

mn67:20.1.pli: Imāni kho, bhikkhave, cattāri bhayāni, idhekacce puggale imasmiṃ dhammavinaye agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajite pāṭikaṅkhitabbānī”ti.
mn67:20.1.eng: These are the four dangers that an individual who gone forth from the lay life to homelessness in this teaching and training should anticipate.”

mn67:20.2.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

mn67:20.3.pli: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandunti.
mn67:20.3.eng: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
